outline.text: Direct observations of N2O5 reactivity on ambient aerosol particles
Timothy H. Bertram,1,2 Joel A. Thornton,1 Theran P. Riedel,3 Ann M. Middlebrook,4
Roya Bahreini,4,5 Timothy S. Bates,6 Patricia K. Quinn,6 and Derek J. Coffman6
Received 28 July 2009; accepted 10 September 2009; published 8 October 2009.
N2O5 reactivity has been measured directly for the first
time on ambient aerosol particles using an entrained aerosol
flow reactor coupled to a custom-built chemical ionization
mass spectrometer at two urban locations during summer.
The observed N2O5 reactivity is a strong function of both
relative humidity (RH) and particle chemical composition.
We show that particulate organic mass loadings, together
with ambient relative humidity, play a leading role in
determining the reaction rate of N2O5 with particles. Our
observed reactivity values are both more variable and, at
times, as much as a factor of ten lower than currently
implemented large-scale model parameterizations would
predict. Such discrepancies have likely consequences for
predictions of NOx availability and ozone production,
and the sensitivity of these quantities to aerosol particle
loadings. Citation: Bertram, T. H., J. A. Thornton, T. P. Riedel,
A. M. Middlebrook, R. Bahreini, T. S. Bates, P. K. Quinn, and
D. J. Coffman (2009), Direct observations of N2O5 reactivity on
ambient aerosol particles, Geophys. Res. Lett., 36, L19803,
Introduction
[2] The production of tropospheric ozone (O3), a criteria
air pollutant and potent greenhouse gas, is a complex
function of nitrogen oxides (NOx = NO + NO2), volatile
organic compounds (VOC), sunlight, and trace oxidants
such as the hydroxyl radical (OH). O3 production is non-
linearly dependent on NOx abundance and thus accurate
description of the processes that remove NOx radicals is
critical for predicting the down-wind influence of anthro-
pogenic emissions on tropospheric O3. Global modeling
studies suggest that nocturnal processes involving the
reactions of the nitrate radical (NO3) and N2O5 account
for 50% of the globally averaged annual net NOx removal
[Dentener and Crutzen, 1993]. However, the impact of
nocturnal NOx removal processes on the tropospheric O3
budget continues to be limited by uncertainty in the reaction
rate of N2O5 with aerosol particles.
[3] The influence of N2O5 on the removal of atmospheric
NOx radicals is determined by the product of the probability

10 mm) were measured with two differential mobility
particle sizing instruments and aerodynamic particle sizer.
Sub-micron particle composition was measured by an
Aerodyne quadrupole aerosol mass spectrometer [Jayne et
[6] We interpret these results using a newly developed
parameterization of g(N2O5) [Bertram and Thornton, 2009]
that is driven by observations of particle composition and
RH, and calculations of H2O(l) as determined by the aerosol
inorganics model (AIM Model II) [Carslaw et al., 1995].
This approach permits us to directly assess the dependence
of the observed g(N2O5) on the factors outlined in section 1.
Observed Dependence of g(N2O5) on Particle
Chemical Composition

particle loadings were rather uniform (mean Sa = 108 ± 35,

observed in Boulder. Co-located measurements of g(N2O5)
and particle phase state [Martin et al., 2008] will clearly
allow such distinctions to be made in the future.
[11] The behavior of g(N2O5) observed in Seattle, at
higher RH, more clearly illustrates the importance of
understanding POM in order to assess the factors control-
ling g(N2O5). The dependence of g(N2O5) on POM/SO4
was observed during a stagnation episode in which most of
the POM mass growth was likely due to SOA formation as
indicated by the fraction of POM that is measured to be
highly oxidized (see Figure S4). In light of the above
expectations, the decreasing g(N2O5) with increasing
POM/SO4
2 can be hypothesized to be a result of: i) a
relative decrease in the particulate water mass fraction,
following increased partitioning of organics that are less
hygroscopic than AS (i.e. DH2O(l)/DPOM  0), leading to
both an increased nitrate effect [Wahner et al., 1998] and a
possible H2O(l) limitation [Thornton et al., 2003], and/or
ii) an increasing role of organic coatings that limit either
N2O5 surface accommodation or N2O5 accessibility to
H2O(l).
[12] To examine these suppositions, we first calculate
[H2O(l)] and [H2O(l)]/[NO3
extremes of POM hygroscopicity: i) POM does not con-
tribute to H2O(l) uptake, and ii) POM is highly hygroscopic,
contributing significantly to H2O(l) (POM treated as
malonic acid) (Figure 1b). In both cases [H2O(l)] is suffi-
ciently high (>20M), so as not to suppress g(N2O5) directly.

uncertainty in its determination. The dashed black line depicts g(N2O5) as parameterized for regions where direct
measurements of g(N2O5) were not available.
The dependence of Flost on g(N2O5) and NO3 reactivity, as
calculated using a time-dependent chemical box model (see
SI) for characteristic summer and winter conditions, is
shown in Figure 3. We chose conditions (e.g., temperature
and NO3 reactivity) in order to bracket the range of possible
sensitivities to g(N2O5). In our summer calculations, Flost is
primarily limited by the NO3 production rate and nearly
independent of g(N2O5) due to assuming high loadings of
biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC), which
increase NO3 reactivity, and warmer temperatures, which
shift the N2O5-NO3 equilibrium in favor of NO3. The result
is that at high NO3 reactivity the nocturnal loss of NOx is
independent of g(N2O5). During winter, BVOC emissions
are significantly smaller, and lower temperatures shift the
N2O5-NO3 equilibrium in favor of N2O5. As a result, Flost is
far more sensitive to g(N2O5) during winter than in summer.
These calculations illustrate the acute sensitivity of the NOx
budget to changes in g(N2O5) between 1  104 and 0.1
and imply that the NOx lifetime is strongly dependent on
NO3 reactivity at low g(N2O5).
[15] In addition to accurate predictions of the total
nocturnal NOx loss, models must also correctly attribute
that loss between the N2O5 and NO3 channels to achieve a
realistic sensitivity of the NOx budget to changes in VOC,
temperature, and particle loadings. Our modeling shows this
branching is sensitive to g(N2O5) for the majority of likely
conditions. The reaction products for the two channels have
different effects on oxidant concentrations and particle mass
loadings: the products of NO3 homogeneous reactions can
